data-cy="document-description">The document presents a comprehensive analysis of targeted credential phishing threats over the past decade, detailing the evolution of attack methods and defenses. It highlights crucial developments like SMS interception, two-factor authentication vulnerabilities, and the importance of security keys and OAuth. The report outlines various actors involved in these attacks and suggests enhanced protective measures to combat ongoing threats.</p><div><div class="CategoryLinks_root__f1kT8"><div class="pills-list What we don&#x27;t see in targeted phishing.
 " class="SlidePreview_thumbnailNoScript__AJfsn"/></noscript><div class="thumbnail SlidePreview_thumbnail__ssUWW" style="aspect-ratio:720 / 405"></div></a><div class="" id=":R48j5r6:" popover="auto" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R48j5r6"></div></div><div class="SlidePreview_root__MxIrt"><a class="link Link_root__vn3ab slide-preview SlidePreview_preview__eU_kp Link_primary__Iq4CI Link_medium__PK_qw" aria-describedby="slide-preview-4" id="slide-preview-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R4aj5r6:" popovertarget=":R4aj5r6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R4aj5r6" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/10-years-of-targeted-credential-phishing-billy-leonard/83684578#5"><span class="text Text_root__RtCPC weight-regular Text_xsmall__X6YLp"><span>5</span></span><noscript><img src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/copyof10yearsoftargetedcredentialphishing-msftfinal-171209002251/85/BlueHat-v17-10-Years-of-Targeted-Credential-Phishing-Billy-Leonard-5-320.jpg" alt="Threat Analysis Group

Targeted attacks are all really advanced.

The Early Days.

This study explores the application of Support Vector\nRegression (SVR) for forecasting wheat yields in Uzbekistan, utilizing soil fertility indicators as key\npredictive features. Unlike conventional linear regression models, SVR effectively captures complex nonlinear interactions between soil physicochemical properties and crop productivity, thereby offering\nimproved adaptability to real-world agricultural conditions. The dataset comprises essential soil\nattributes, including nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), potassium (K), pH, organic carbon (OC), electrical\nconductivity (EC), and micro-nutrient concentrations. Data preprocessing involved feature\nstandardization, K-nearest neighbor (KNN) imputation for handling missing values, and correlation\nanalysis to select the most influential variables. The dataset was partitioned using an 80/20 stratified split,\nand the SVR model with a radial basis function (RBF) kernel was optimized through 5-fold crossvalidation and exhaustive grid search for hyperparameter tuning. The optimized SVR model achieved a\ncoefficient of determination (𝑅\n2\n) of 0.87 and demonstrated a low root mean square error (RMSE),\noutperforming baseline regression methods. Model interpretability was enhanced using SHapley Additive\nexPlanations (SHAP), which identified soil pH, organic carbon, and available phosphorus as the most\nsignificant predictors of wheat yield—findings consistent with established agronomic principles. Overall,\nthe results confirm SVR’s potential as a robust, scalable, and interpretable tool for precision agriculture,\noffering practical insights for site-specific yield forecasting and promoting sustainable land management\npractices in Uzbekistan.\nKEYWORDS\nSupport Vector Regression (SVR), Wheat Yield Prediction, Precision Agriculture, Machine Learning, Nonlinear Models, Uzbekistan, Model Evaluation.\n","tags":["support vector regression","wheat yield prediction","precision agriculture"],"url":"https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/application-and-analysis-of-ensemble-algorithms-in-solving-regression-problems-7fbc/283066216","userLogin":"acijjournal","userName":"acijjournal","viewCount":62},{"algorithmId":"4","displayTitle":"Microsoft However, the linear models utilized, partial least square (PLS) and principal component regression (PCR) achieved unsatisfactory performances of meat physical attributes prediction. Hence, in this research, for its inherent advantages in modelling nonlinear system, artificial neural network (ANN) is augmented to the components of PCR and PLS. Through the augmentation, the principal component neural network (PCNN) and latent variable neural network (LVNN) models are developed. From the results obtained, it shows that PCNN and LVNN successfully surpassed their respective linear versions of PCR and PLS by 70% higher shear force prediction performances. The LVNN proved to achieve the best prediction in breast meat with root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP) of 0.0769 kg and coefficient of determination (RP 2) of 0.8201 whilst for drumsticks, RMSEP=0.1494 kg and RP 2=0.8606.
